title: RFU face eye-watering bill of more than £6m if England win World Cup
text:
The RFU are in line for an eye-watering bill of more than £6million in bonuses to players and staff if England beat South Africa in the World Cup final.

Having opted not to take out insurance over the incentives, the already cash-strapped organisation now face another financial body blow.

England's squad of 32 players, which includes late call-up Ben Spencer, could all split a pot of £5m, which is set to rise to £6m when the coaching staff and other management figures are included, according to the Telegraph.

The England players and staff are in line for bonus payments if they win the World Cup

If Eddie Jones's side beat the Springboks then the prize money itself will only be £325,000, pocket change in comparison with the bonuses the RFU would have to shell out.

With no autumn internationals this year to help fill the coffers and the total cost of the World Cup campaign expected to reach around £3m, the immediate outlook is bleak.

Last year the RFU declared a loss of £30.9m and subsequently warned that there were 'uncertain times' ahead.

As they tightened the purse strings, the decision was taken not to take out insurance on the bonus payments for the World Cup.

Eddie Jones and his coaching staff will also be among the recipients of bonuses

With no insurance policy, the RFU have to incur the total costs, which would be the biggest in tournament history if England win on Saturday.

The Telegraph report that the semi-final victory over New Zealand meant a bonus payment of more than £1.2m in itself.

A long-term prognosis is expected to be more sunny if England lift the Webb Ellis trophy.

Chances of a major new sponsorship deal with the team will no doubt improve if they become champions and there would also be the possibility of a hike in ticket prices at Twickenham, though clearly that would be unpopular among match-going fans.

Autumn Tests against New Zealand, Argentina and Australia will help boost revenue in 2020 and equity firm CVC could also pump much needed cash into the bank if they seal a deal for 15 per cent of the Six Nations commercial rights for more than £300m.
